Aboveground carbon biomass (AGB) is a crucial component in monitoring the carbon cycle on both local and global scales. A recent state-of-the-art light detection and ranging (LiDAR) mission from NASA's Global Ecosystem Dynamics Investigation (GEDI) provides global yet non-continuous sparse measurements of vegetation parameters, including AGB estimates with 60-meter along-track and 600-meter across-track gaps between footprints. To address this limitation, we apply a physics-informed deep network to generate a 30-meter resolution, wall-to-wall continuous AGB estimate in the Continental USA (CONUS) for the summertime (June-August) 2021 period.

Our model is trained on over one million GEDI footprints using a combination of radar and optical imagery. Additionally, we incorporate a measure of photosynthetic intensity as captured by solar-induced fluorescence (SIF)-based gross primary production (GPP). SIF-based GPP is a key physical parameter regulating AGB. We validate our results using field-based AGB observations and evaluate their consistency across climate zones.

We use a combination of radar and optical hyperspectral imagery from Sentinel-1 and Sentinel-2, as well as SIF-based GPP from the OCO-2 mission. The data is processed to produce near-cloud-free optical imagery by taking the median value of non-cloudy pixels as defined by the scene classification layer (SCL) of Sentinel-2. We perform grid cell geospatial matching to combine the dataset together.

Our model is benchmarked against linear regressor (LR), random forests (RF), and extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) algorithms due to their reported robustness in climate-related tasks. We implement a masked variation of UNet due to the sparsity of our target AGB variable. The models are optimized using a randomized grid search and a k-fold cross-validation approach with a 90-10 training-testing split. We use the Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 0.01 and root-mean-squared error (RMSE) as our loss function.

Our results show that a masked variation of UNet has the lowest validation RMSE of 37.93 ± 1.36 Mg C/ha, compared to 52.30 ± 0.03 Mg C/ha for the random forest algorithm. Furthermore, models that learn from SIF-based GPP in addition to radar and optical imagery reduce validation RMSE by almost 10% and the standard deviation by 40%.

We apply our model to measure losses in AGB from the recent 2021 Caldor wildfire in California and validate our analysis with Sentinel-based burn index.
